sp.speaker: Scrivener.
sp.l: Then was it as ye prayed to have it I wot,
But in reading and pointing there was made some fault.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I wot not, but it made all my matter to halt.

sp.speaker: Scrivener.
sp.l: How say you, is this mine original or no?

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: The self same that I wrote out of, so mote I go.

sp.speaker: Scrivener.
sp.l: Look you on your own fist, and I will look on this,
And let this man be judge whether I read amiss.
To mine own dear coney bird, sweet heart, and pigsny,
Good mistress Custance, present these by and by.
How now? doth not this superscription agree?

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Read that is within, and there ye shall the fault see.

sp.speaker: Scrivener.
sp.l: Sweet mistress, where as I love you, nothing at all
Regarding your richesse and substance: chief of all
For your personage, beauty, demeanour and „Äà‚óä„Äâ
I commend me unto you: never a whit
sorry to hear report of your good welfare.
For (As I hear say) such your conditions are,
That ye be worthy favour: of no living man
To be abhorred: of every honest man
To be taken for a woman inclined to vice
Nothing at all: to virtue giving her due price.
Wherefore concerning marriage, ye are thought
Such a fine paragon, as never honest man bought.
And now by these presents I do you advertise,
That I am minded to marry you: in no wise
For your goods and substance: I can be content
To take you as you are: if ye will be my wife,
Ye shall be assured for the time of my life,
I will keep you right well: from good raiment and fare,
Ye shall not be kept: but in sorrow and care
Ye shall in no wise live: at your own liberty,
Do and say what ye lust: ye shall never please me
But when ye are merry: I will been all sad
When ye are sorry: I will be very glad
When ye seek your heart's ease: I will be unkind
At no time: in me shall ye much gentleness find.
But all things contrary to your will and mind
Shall be done otherwise: I will not be behind
To speak: and as for all they that would do you wrong,
(I will so help and maintain ye) shall not live long.
Nor any foolish doit shall cumber you, but I,
Ay, who ere say nay, will stick by you till I die.
Thus good mistress Custance, the lord you save and keep.
From me Roister Doister, whether I wake or sleep,
Who fauoureth you no less, (Ye may be bold)
Than this letter purporteth, which ye have unfold.
Now sir, what default can ye find in this letter?

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Of truth in my mind there can not be a better.

sp.speaker: Scrivener.
sp.l: Then was the fault in reading, and not in writing,
no nor I dare say in the form of enditing,
But who read this letter, that it sounded so naught?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: I red it in deed.

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.l: Ye red it not as ye ought.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Why thou wretched villain was all this same fault in thee?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: I knock your costard if ye offer to strike me.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Strikest thou in deed? and I offer but in jest?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Yea and rap you again except ye can sit in rest.
And I will no longer tarry hear me believe.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: What wilt thou be angry, and I do thee forgive?
Fare thou well scribbler, I cry thee mercy in deed.

sp.speaker: Scrivener.
sp.l: Fare ye well bibbler, and worthily may ye speed.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: If it were another but thou, it were a knave.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Ye are another yourself sir, the lord us both save,
Albeit in this matter I must your pardon crave,
Alas would ye wish in me the wit that ye have?
But as for my fault I can quickly amend,
I will show Custance it was I that did offend.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: By so doing her anger may be reformed.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: But if by no entreaty she will be turned,
Then set light by her and been as testy as she,
And do your force upon her with extremity.

sp.speaker: R. Roister.
sp.l: Come on therefore let us go home in sadness.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: That if force shall need all may be in a readiness,
And as for this letter hardly let all go,
We will know where she refuse you for that or no.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: Is there any man but I Sym Suresby alone,
That would have taken such an enterprise him upon,
In such an outrageous tempest as this was.
Suche a dangerous gulf of the sea to pass.
I think verily Neptune's mighty godship,
Was angry with some that was in our ship,
And but for the honesty which in me he found,
I think for the others sake we had been drowned.
But fie on that servant which for his master's wealth
Will stick for to hazard both his life and his health.
My master Gavin Goodluck after me a day
Because of the weather, thought best his ship to stay,
And now that I have the rough surges so well passed,
God grant I may find all things safe here at last.
Then will I think all my travail well spent,
Now the first point wherefore my master hath me sent
Is to salute dame Christian Custance his wife,
Espoused: whom he tendereth no less than his life,
I must see how it is with her well or wrong,
And whether for him she doth not now think long:
Then to other friends I have a message or ‚óèway,
And then so to return and meet him on the way.
Now will I go k‚óè‚óècke that I may dispatch with speed,
But lo forth cometh herself happily in deed.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I come to see if any more stirring be here,
But what stranger is this, which death to me appear ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: Sym suresbys
sp.l: I will speak to her: dame the lord you save and see.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: What friend Sym Suresby? Forsooth right welcome ye be,
How doth mine own Gavin Goodluck ‚ñ™ I pray the tell?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: When he knoweth of your health he will be perfect well.

sp.speaker: S. Suresby
sp.l: If he have perfect health, I am as I would be.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: Such news will please him well, this is as it should be.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I think now long for him.

sp.speaker: Sym S.
sp.l: And he as long for you.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: When will he be at home?

sp.speaker: Sym. S.
sp.l: His heart is here ‚óèen now
His body cometh after.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I would see that fain.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: As fast as wind and sail can carry it a main.
But what two men are yond coming hitherward?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Now I shrew their best Christmas cheeks both togetherward.

div.head: Actus. iiij. scaena. iij.
div.stage: Christian Custance. Sym Suresby. Ralph Roister. Mathew Merrygreek. Trupeny.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: What mean these lewd fellows thus to trouble me still?
Sym Suresby here perchance shall thereof deem some ill,
And shall suspect in me some point of naughtiness,
And they come hitherward.

sp.speaker: Sym S.
sp.l: What is their business?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I have naught to them, nor they to me in sadness.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: Let us hearken them, somewhat there is I fear it.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I will speak out aloud best, that she may hear it.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay alas; ye may so fear her out of her wit.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: By the cross of my sword, I will hurt her no whit.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Will ye do no harm in deed, shall I trust your word?

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: By Roister Doister's faith I will speak but in board.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: Let us hearken them, somewhat there is I fears it.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I will speak out aloud, I care not who hear it:
Sirs, see that my harness, my tergat, and my shield,
Be made as bright now, as when I was last in field,
As white as I should to war again to morrow:
For sick shall I be, but I work some folk sorrow.
Therefore see that all shine as bright as saint George,
Or as doth a key newly come from the smith's forge.
I would have my sword and harness to shine so bright,
that I might therewith dim mine enemy's sight,
I would have it cast beams as fast I tell you plain,
As doth the glittering grass after a shower of rain.
And see that in case I should need to come to arming,
All things may be ready at a minute's warning,
For such chance may chance in an hour, do ye hear?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: As perchance shall not chance again in seven year.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Now draw we near to her, and here what shall be said.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: But I would not have you make her too much afraid.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Well found sweet wife (I trust) for all this your sour look.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Wife? why call ye me wife?

sp.speaker: Sim S.
sp.l: Wife? this gear goeth acrook.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay mistress Custance, I warrant you, our letter
Is not as we red e'en now, but much better,
And where ye half stomached this gentleman afore,
For this same letter, ye will love him now therefore,
Nor it is not this letter though ye were a Queen,
That should break marriage between you twain I ween.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I did not refuse him for the letter's sake.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Then ye are content me for your husband to take.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: You for my husband to take? nothing less truly.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Yea say so, sweet spouse, afore strangers hardly.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: And though I have here his letter of love with me,
Yet his ring and tokens he sent, keep safe with ye.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: A mischief take his tokens, and him and thee too.
But what prate I with fools? have I naught else to do?
Come in with me Sym Suresby to take some repast.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: I must ere I drink by your leave, go in all haste,
To a place or two, with earnest letters of his.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Then come drink here with me.

sp.speaker: S. S.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: Do not miss
You shall have a token to your master with you.

sp.speaker: Sym suresbys
sp.l: No tokens this time gramercies, God be with you.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Surely this fellow misd√©emeth some ill in me,
Which thing but God help, will go near to spill me.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Yea farewell fellow, and tell thy master Goodluck
that he cometh too late of this blossom to pluck.
Let him keep him there still, or at least wise make no haste,
As for his labour hither he shall spend in waste.
His betters be in place now.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: As long as it will hold.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I will be even with thee thou beast, thou mayst be bold.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Will ye have us then?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I will never have thee.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Then will I have you?

sp.speaker: C. Cust.
sp.l: No, the devil shall have thee.
I have gotten this hour more shame and harm by thee,
Than all thy life days thou canst do me honesty.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Why now may ye see what it cometh too in the end,
To make a deadly foe of your most loving friend:
And iwis this letter if ye would hear it now.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I will hear none of it.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: In faith would ravish you.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: He hath stained my name for ever this is clear.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I can make all as well in an hour.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: As ten year.
How say ye, will ye have him?

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Will ye take him?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I defy him.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: At my word?.

sp.speaker: C. Cust.
sp.l: A shame take him.
Waste no more wind, for it will never been.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: This one fault with twain shall be mended, ye shall see.
Gentle mistress Custance now, good mistress Custance,
Honey mistress Custance now, sweet mistress Custance,
Golden mistress Custance now, white mistress Custance,
Silken mistress Custance now, fair mistress Custance.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Faith rather than to marry with such a doltish lout,
I would match myself with a beggar out of doubt.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Then I can say no more, to speed we are not like,
Except ye rap out a rag of your rhetoric.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Speak not of winning me: for it shall never be so.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Yes dame, I will have you whether ye will or no,
I command you to love me, wherefore should ye not?
Is not my love to you chafing and burning hot?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Too her, that is well said.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Shall I so break my brain
To dote upon you, and ye not love us again?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Well said yet.

sp.speaker: C. Cust.
sp.l: Go to thougoose.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: I say ‚óèit Custance,
in case ye will not haze, well, better yes perchance.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Avant lozel, pick thee hence.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Well sir, ye perceive,
For all your kind offer, she will not you receive.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Then a straw for her, and a straw for her again,
She shall not be my wife, would she never so fain,
No and though she would be at ten thousand pound cost.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Lo dame, ye may see what an husband ye have lost.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Yea, no force, a jewel much better lost than found.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Ah, ye will not believe how this doth my heart wound.
How should a marriage between you be toward,
If both parties draw back, and become so froward.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Nay dame, I will fire thee out of thy house,
And destroy thee and all thine, and that by and by.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay for the passion of God sir, do not so.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Yes, except she will say yea to that she said no.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: And what, be there no officers trow we, in town
To check idle loiterers bragging up and down?
Where be they, by whom vagabonds should be repressed?
That poor silly widows might live in peace and rest.
Shall I never rid thee out of my company?
I will call for help, what hough, come forth Trupenie.

sp.speaker: Trupeny.
sp.l: Anon. What is your will mistress? did ye call me?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Yea, go run apace, and as fast as may be,
Pray Tristram trusty, my most assured friend,
To be here by and by, that he may me defend.

sp.speaker: Trupeny.
sp.l: That message so quickly shall be done by God's grace,
That at my return ye shall say, I went apace.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Then shall we see I trow, whe‚óè‚óè ere ye shall do me harm,

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Yes in faith Kit, I shall thee and thine so charm,
That all women incarnate by thee may beware.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Nay, as for charming me, come hither if thou dare,
I shall clout thee till thou stink, both thee and thy train,
And coil thee mine own hands, and send thee home again.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Yea sayst thou me that dame? dost thou me threaten?
Go we, I will see whether I shall be beaten.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay for the pash of God, let me now treat peace,
For bloodshed will there be in case this strife increase.
Ah good dame Custance, take better way with you.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Let him do his worst.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Yield in time.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Come hence thou.

div.head: Actus. iiij. scaena. iiij.
div.stage: Christian Custance. Anot Alyface. Tibet T. M Mumblecrust.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: So sirrah, if I should not with him take this way,
I should not be rid of him I think till doom's day,
I will call forth my folks, that without any mocks
If he come again we may give him raps and knocks.
Madge Mumblecrust, come forth, and Tibet talk apace.
Yea and come forth too, mistress Annot Alyface.

sp.speaker: Annot Aly.
sp.l: I come.

sp.speaker: Tibet.
sp.l: And I am here.

sp.speaker: M. Mumb.
sp.l: And I am here too at length.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Like warriors if need been, ye must show your strength
The man that this day hath thus beguiled you,
Is Ralph Roister Doister, whom ye know well enough,
The most lout and dastard that ever on ground trodden.

sp.speaker: Tib Talk.
sp.l: I see all folk mock him when he goeth abroad.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: What pretty maid? will ye talk when I speak?

sp.speaker: Tib. Talk.
sp.l: No forsooth good mistress.

sp.speaker: C. Cust.
sp.l: Will ye my tale break?
He threatneth to come hither with all his force to fight,
I charge you if he come, on him with all your might.

sp.speaker: M. Mumbl.
sp.l: I with my distaff will reach him one rap.

sp.speaker: Tib Talk.
sp.l: And I with my new broom will sweep him one swap,
And then with our great club I will reach him one rap.

sp.speaker: An. Aliface.
sp.l: And I with our skimmer will fling him one flap.

sp.speaker: Tib. Talk.
sp.l: Then Trupenie's firefork will him shrewdly fray,
And you with the spit may drive him quite away.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Go make all ready, that it may be e'en so.

sp.speaker: Tib. Talk.
sp.l: For my part I shrew them that last about it go.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Trupeny did promise me to run a great pace,
My friend Tristram trusty to fet into this place.
In deed he dwelleth hence a good start I confess:
But yet a quick messenger might twice since as I guess,
Have gone and come again. Ah yond I spy him now.

sp.speaker: Trupeny.
sp.l: Ye are a slow goer sir, I make God avow.
My mistress Custance will in me put all the blame,
Your legs be longer than mine: come apace for shame.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I can thee thank Trupenie, thou hast done right well.

sp.speaker: Trupeny.
sp.l: Mistress since I went no grass hath grown on my heel,
But master Tristram trusty here maketh no speed.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: That he came at all I thank him in very deed,
For now have I need of the help of some wise man.

sp.speaker: T. trusty.
sp.l: Then may I be gone again, for none such I m.

sp.speaker: Trupeny.
sp.l: Ye may been by your going: for no alderman
Can go I dare say, a sadder pace than ye can.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Trupenie get thee in, thou shalt among them know,
How to use thyself, like a proper man I trow.

sp.speaker: Trupeny.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: Now Tristram trusty I thank you right much.
For at my first sending to come ye never grutch.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Dame Custance God ye save, and while my life shall last,
For my friend Goodluck's sake ye shall not send in waste.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: He shall give you thanks.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: I will do much for his sake

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: But alack, I fear, great displeasure shall be take.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: For a foolish matter.

sp.speaker: T. T.
sp.l: What is your cause

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I am ill accumbered with a couple of daws.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Nay weep not woman: but tell me what your cause is
As concerning my friend is any thing amiss?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: No not on my part: but here was Sym Suresby.

sp.speaker: T. Trustie.
sp.l: He was with me and told me so.

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: And he stood by
While Ralph Roister Doister with help of Merrygreek,
For promise of marriage did unto me seek.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: And had ye made any promise before them twain.

sp.speaker: C. Custance ‚ñ™
sp.l: No I had rather be torn in pieces and slain,
No man hath my faith and troth, but Gavin Goodluck,
And that before Suresby did I say, and there stuck,
But of certain letters there were such words spoken.

sp.speaker: T. Trustie.
sp.l: He told me that too.

sp.speaker: C. Cust.
sp.l: And of a ring and token.
That Suresby I spied, did more than half suspect,
That I my faith to Gavin Goodluck did reject.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: But there was no such matter dame Custance in deed?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: If ever my head thought it, God send me ill speed.
Wherefore I beseech you, with me to be a witness,
That in all my life I never intended thing less,
And what a brainsick fool Ralph Roister Doister is,
Yourself know well enough.

sp.speaker: T. Trust.
sp.l: Ye say full true iwis.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Because to been his wife I ne grant nor apply,
Hither will he come he sweareth by and by,
To kill both me and mine, and beat down my house flat.
Therefore I pray your aid.

sp.speaker: T. T.
sp.l: I warrant you that.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Have I so many years lived a sober life,
And showed myself honest, maid, widow, and wife,
And now to be abused in such a vile sort,
Ye see how poor widows live all void of comfort.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: I warrant him do you no harm nor wrong at all.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: No, but Mathew Merrygreek doth me most appall,
That he would join himself with such a wretched lout.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: He doth it for a jest I know him out of doubt,
And here cometh Merrygreek.

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: Then shall we here his mind.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Custance and trusty both, I do you here well find.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Ah Mathew Merrygreek, ye have used me well.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Now for altogether ye must your answer tell.
Will ye have this man, woman? or else will ye not?
Else will be come never bore so brim nor tossed so hot.

sp.speaker: Tris. And Cu.
sp.l: But why join ye with him.

sp.speaker: T. Tr.
sp.l: For mirth?

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: Or else in sadness

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: The more fond of you both hardly thematter guess.

sp.speaker: Tristram.
sp.l: Lo how say ye dame?

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Why do ye think dame Custance
That in this wooing I have meant ought but pastance?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Much things ye spoke I wot, to maintain his dotage.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: But well might ye judge I spoke it all in mockage,
For why? Is Roister Doister a fit husband for you?

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: I dare say ye never thought it.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: No to God I vow.
And did not I know afore of the insurance
Between Gavin Goodluck, and Christian Custance?
And did not I for the nonce, by my conveyance,
Read his letter in a wrong sense for dalliance?
That if you could have take it up at the first bound,
We should thereat such a sport and pastime have found,
That all the whole town should have been the merrier.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Ill ache your heads both, I was never wearier,
Nor never more verte since the first day I was born.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: But very well I wist he here did all in scorn.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: But I feared thereof to take dishonesty.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: This should both have made sport, and showed your honesty
And Goodluck I dare swear, your wit therein would low.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Yea, being no worse than we know it to be now.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: And nothing yet too late, for when I come to him,
Hither will he repair with a sheep's look full grim,
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ force and violence to drive you to yield.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: If ye two bid me, we will with him pitch a field,
I and my maids together.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Let us see, be bold.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Ye shall see women's war.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: That fight will I behold

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: If occasion serve, taking his part full brim,
I will strike at you, but the rap shall light on him.
When we first appear.

sp.speaker: C. Cust.
sp.l: Then will I run away
As though I were afeard.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Do you that part well play
And I will sue for peace.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: And I will set him on.
Then will he look as fierce as a Cotssold lion.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: But when ghost thou for him?

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: That do I very now.

sp.speaker: C. Custance
sp.l: Ye shall find us here.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Well god have mercy on you.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: There is no cause of fear, the least boy in the street:

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Nay, the least girl I have, will make him take his feet.
But hark, methink they make preparation.

sp.speaker: T. Trustie.
sp.l: No force, it will be a good recreation.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I will stand within, and step forth speedily,
And so make as though I ran away dreadfully.

div.head: Actus. iiij. scaena. vii.
div.stage: R Royster. m. Merrygreek. C. Custance. D Doughtie. Harpax. Tristram Trusty.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Now sirs, keep your ray, and see your hearts be stout,
But where be these caitiffs, methink they dare not rout,
How sayst thou Merrygreek? What doth Kit Custance say?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: I am loath to tell you.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Tush speak man ‚ñ™ yea or nay?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Forsooth sir, I have spoken for you all that I can.
But if ye win her, ye must e'en play the man,
E'en to fight it out, ye must a man's heart take.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Yes, they shall know, and thou knowest I have a stomach.
A stomach (Quod you) yea, as good as ere man had.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I trow they shall find and feel that I am a lad.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: By this cross I have seen you eat your meat as well,
As any that ere I have seen of or heard tell,
A stomach quod you? he that will that deny
I know was never at dinner in your company.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Nay, the stomach of a man it is that I mean.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay the stomach of an horse or a dog I ween.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Nay a man's stomach with a weapon mean I.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Ten men can scarce match you with a spoon in a pie.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Nay the stomach of a man to try in st‚óè‚óèfe.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: I never saw your stomach cloyed yet in my life.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Tush I mean in strife or fighting to try.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: We shall see how ye will strike now being angry.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Have at thy pate then, and save thy head if thou may.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay then have at your pate again by this day,

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Nay thou mayst not strike at me again in no wise.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: I can not in fight make to you such warrantise:
But as for your foes here let them the bargain buy.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Nay as for they, shall every mother's child die.
And in this my fume a little thing might make me,
To beat down house and all, and else the devil take me.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: If I were as ye be, by gog's dear mother,
I would not leave one stone upon another.
Though she would redeem it with twenty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: It shall be even so, by his lily wounds.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Be not at one with her upon any amends.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: No though she make to me never so many friends.
Not if all the world for her would undertake,
No not God himself neither, shall not her peace make,
On therefore, march forward, soft, stay a while yet.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: On.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Tarry.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Forth.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Back.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: On.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Soft. Now forward set

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: What business have we here? out alas, alas.

sp.speaker: R. Roister.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.
Didst thou see that Merrygreek? how afraid she was?
Didst thou see how she fled apace out of my sight?
Ah good sweet Custance I pity her by this light.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: That tender heart of yours will mar altogether,
Thus will ye be turned with wagging of a feather.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: On sirs, keep your ray.

sp.speaker: M. m
sp.l: On forth, while this gear is hot

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Soft, the arms of Caleys, I have one thing forgotten.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: What lack we now?

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Retire, or else we be all slain.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Back for the pash of God, back sirs, back again.
What is the great matter?

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: This hasty forth going
Had almost brought us all to utter undoing,
It made me forget a thing most necessary.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Well remembered of a captain by saint Mary.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: It is a thing must be had.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Let us have it then.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: But I wot not where nor how.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Then wot not I when.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: But what is it?

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Of a chief thing I am to seek.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Tut so will ye be, when ye have studied a week.
But tell me what it is?

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: I lack yet an head-piece.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: The kitchen collocavit, the best hens to greece,
Run, fetched it Dobinet, and come at once withal,
And bring with thee my potgun, hanging by the wall,
I have seen your head with it full many a time,
Covered as safe as it had been with a screen:
And I warrant it save your head from any stroke,
Except perchance to be amazed with the smoke:
I warrant your head therewith, except for the mist,
As safe as if it were fast locked up in a chest:
And lo here our Dobinet cometh with it now.

sp.speaker: D. Dough.
sp.l: It will cover me to the shoulders well enough.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Let me see it on.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: In faith it doth meetly well.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: There can be no fitter thing. Now ye must us tell
What to do.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Now forth in ray sirs, and stop no more.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Now saint George to borrow, drum dub a dub afore.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: What mean you to do sir, commit manslaughter.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: To kill for‚óèie such, is a matter of laughter.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: And who is it sir, whom ye intend thus to spill?

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Foolish Custance here forceth me against my will.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: And is there no mean your extreme wrath to slake.
She shall some amends unto your good maship make.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I will none amends.

sp.speaker: T. Tr.
sp.l: Is her offence so sore?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: And he were a lout she could have done no more.
She hath called him fool, and dressed him like a fool.
Mocked him like a fool, used him like a fool.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Well yet the sheriff, the justice, or constable,
Her misdemeanour to punish might be able.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: No sir, I mine own self will in this present cause,
Be sheriff, and justice, and whole judge of the laws,
This matter to amend, all officers be I shall,
Constable, bailiff, sergeant.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: And hangman and all.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Yet a noble courage, and the heart of a man
Should more honour win by bearing with a woman.
Therefore take the law, and let her answer thereto.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Merrygreek, the best way were even so to do.
What honour should it be with a woman to fight?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: And what then, will ye thus forgo and less your right?

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Nay, I will take the law on her withouten grace.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Or if your maship could pardon this one trespass.
I pray you forgive her.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Hoh?

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Tush tush sir do not.
Be good master to her.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Hoh?

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Tush I say do not.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: And what shall your people here return straight home?

sp.speaker: R. Roister.
sp.l: Yea, levy the camp sirs, and hence again each one,

sp.speaker: T. Trustie.
sp.l: But be still in readiness if I hap to call,
I can not tell what sudden chance may befall.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Do not off your harness sirs I you advise,
At the least for this fortnight in no manner wise,
Perchance in an hour when all ye think least,
Our master's appetite to fight will be best.
But soft, ere ye go, have once at Custance house.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Soft, what wilt thou do?

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Once discharge my harquebus
and for my heart's ease, have once more with my p‚óètgoon.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Hold thy hands else is all our purpose clean foredone.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: And it cost me my life.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: I say thou shalt not.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: By the mat but I will. Have once more with hail shot
I will have some pennyworth, I will not lose all.

div.head: Actus. iiij. scaena. viij.
div.stage: M. Merrygreek. C. Custance. R. Roister. Tib. T. An. Alyface. M. Mumblecrust. Trupeny. Dobinet Doughtie. Harpax. Two drums with their ensigns.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: What caitiffs are those that so shake my house wall?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Ah sirrah now Custance if ye had so much wit
I would see you ask pardon, and yourselves submit.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Have I still this ado with a couple of fools?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Here ye what she saith?

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: Maidens come forth with your tools

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: In a ray.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Dubba dub sirrah.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: In a ray,
They come suddenly on us.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Dubbadub.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: In a ray.
That ever I was born, we are taken tardy.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Now sirs, quite ourselves like tall men and hardy.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: On afore Trupenie, hold thine own Annot,
On toward them Tibet, for scape us they can not.
Come forth Madge Mumblecrust, „Äà‚óä„Äâ stand fast together.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: God send us a fair day.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: See they march on hither.

sp.speaker: Tib. Talk.
sp.l: But mistress.

sp.speaker: C. C.
sp.l: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Shall I go fet our goose?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: What to do?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: To yonder captain I will turn her loose
And she gape and hiss at him, as she doth at me,
I durst jeopard my hand she will make him flee.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: On forward.

sp.speaker: R R.
sp.l: They come.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Stand.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Mm.
sp.l: Keep.

sp.speaker: C. Custance. (R. R.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Strike.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Take heed.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Well said Trupenie.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.l: Ah whoresons.

sp.speaker: Cc.
sp.l: Well done in deed

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Hold thine own Harpax, down with them Dobinet.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Now Madge, there Annot: now stick them Tibet.

sp.speaker: Tib. Talk.
sp.l: All my chief quarrel is to this same little knave,
That beguiled me last day, nothing shall him save.

sp.speaker: D. Dough.
sp.l: Down with this little quean, that hath at me such spite,
Save you from her master, it is a very sprite.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I myself will mounsire grand captain undertake,

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: They win ground.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Save yourself sir, for god's sake.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Out, alas, I am slain, help.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Save yourself.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Alas.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay then, have at you mistress.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Thou hittest me, alas.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: I will strike at Custance here.

sp.speaker: R R.
sp.l: Thou hittest me.

sp.speaker: Mm.
sp.l: So I will

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay mistress Custance.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Alas, thou hittest me still.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Save yourself sir.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Help, out alas I am slain

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Truce, hold your hands, truce for a pissing while or twain:
Now how say you Custance, for saving of your life,
Will ye yield and grant to be this gentman's wife?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Ye told me he loved me, call ye this love?

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: He loved a while even like a turtle dove.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Gay love God save it, so soon hot, so soon cold.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: I am sorry for you: he could love you yet so he could.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Nay by cocks precious she shall be none of mine.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Why so?

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Come away, by the mat she is mankine.
I durst adventure the loss of my right hand,
If she did not flee her other husband:
And see if she prepare not again to fight.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: What then? saint George to borrow, our lady's knight ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Slay else whom she will, by gog she shall not slay me.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Rather than to be slain, I will flee.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Too it again, my knightesses, down with them all.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Away, away, away, she will else kill us all.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Nay stick to it, like an hardy man and a tall.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: O bones, thou bittest me. Away, or else die we shall.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Away for the pash of our sweet lord Jesus Christ.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Away lout and lubber, or I shall be thy priest.
So this field is ours we have driven them all away.

sp.speaker: Tib. Talk.
sp.l: Thanks to God mistress, ye have had a fair day.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Well now go ye in, and make yourself some good cheer.

sp.speaker: Oens pariter.
sp.l: We go.

sp.speaker: T. Trust.
sp.l: Ah sir, what a field we have had here.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Friend Tristram, I pray you be a witness with me.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Dame Custance, I shall depose for your honesty,
And now fare ye well, except some thing else ye would.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Not now, but when I need to send I will be bold.
I thank you for these pains. And now I will get me in,
Now Roister Doister will no more wooing begin.

div.head: Actus. v. scaena. i.
div.l: Sym Suresby my trusty man, now advise thee well,
And see that no false surmises thou me tell,
Was there such ado about Custance of a truth?

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: To report that I heard and saw, to me is ruth,
But both my duty and name and property,
Warneth me to you to show fidelity.
It may be well enough, and I wish it so to be,
She may herself discharge and try her honesty,
Yet their claim to her methought was very large,
For with letters rings and tokens, they did her charge.
Which when I heard and saw I would none to you bring.

sp.speaker: G. Goodl.
sp.l: No by saint Marry, I allow thee in that thing.
Ah sirrah, now I see truth in the proverb old,
All things that shineth is not by and by pure gold,
If any do live a woman of honesty ‚ñ™
I would have sworn Christian Custance had been she.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: Sir, though I to you be a servant true and just.
Yet do not ye therefore your faithful spouse mistrust.
But examine the matter, and if ye shall it find,
To be all well, be not ye for my words unkind ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: G. Goodl.
sp.l: I shall do that is right, and as I see cause why.
But here cometh Custance forth, we shall know by and by.

div.head: Actus. v. scaena. ij.
div.stage: C Custance. Gawyn Goodluck. Sym Suresby.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: I come forth to see and hearken for news good,
For about this hour is the time of likelihood,
That Gavin Goodluck by the sayings of Suresby,
Would be at home, and lo yond I see him I.
What Gavin Goodluck, the only hope of my life,
Welcome home, and kiss me your true espoused wife.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: Nay soft dame Custance, I must first by your licence,
See whether all things be clear in your conscience,
I hear of your doings to me very strange.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: What fear ye that my faith towards you should change?

sp.speaker: Gawyn Good.
sp.l: I must needs mistrust ye be elsewhere entangled,
For I hear that certain men with you have wrangled
About the promise of marriage by you to them made.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Could any man's report your mind therein persuade?

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: Well, ye must therein declare yourself to stand clear,
Else I and you dame Custance may not join this year ‚ñ™

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Then would I were dead, and fair laid in my grave,
Ah Suresby, is this the honesty that ye have?
To hurt me with your report, not knowing the thing.

sp.speaker: Sun Sure.
sp.l: If ye be honest my words can hurt you nothing.
But what I heard and saw, I might not but report.

sp.speaker: C. Custance
sp.l: Ah lord, help poor widows, destitute of comfort.
Truly most dear spouse, naught was done but for pastance.

sp.speaker: G. Good.
sp.l: But such kind of sporting is homely dalliance.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: If ye knew the truth, ye would take all in good part.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: By your leave I am not half well skilled in that art.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: It was none but Roister Doister that foolish mome.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: Yea Custance, better (They say) a bad 'scuse than none.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Why Tristram trusty sir, your true and faithful friend,
Was privy both to the beginning and the end.
Let him be the judge, and for me testify.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: I will the more credit that he shall verify,
And because I will the truth know e'en as it is,
I will to him myself, and know all without miss.
Come on Sym Suresby, that before my friend thou may
Avouch the same words, which thou didst to me say.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: O lord, how necessary it is now of days,
That each body live uprightly all manner ways,
For let never so little a gap be open,
And be sure of this, the worst shall be spoken
How innocent stand I in this for deed or thought?
And yet see what mistrust towards me it hath wrought
But thou lord knowest all folks thoughts and eke intents
And thou art the deliverer of all innocentes.
Thou didst help the adulteress that she might be amended,
Much more than help lord, that never ill intended.
Thou didst help Susanna, wrongfully accused,
And no less dost thou see lord, how I am now abused,
Thou didst help Hester, when she should have died,
Help also good lord, that my truth may be tried.
Yet if Gavin Goodluck with Tristram trusty speak.
I trust of ill report the force shall be but weak,
and lo‚óè yond they come sadly talking together,
I will abide, and not shrink for their coming hither.

div.head: Actus. v. scaena. iiij.
div.stage: Gawyn Goodluck, Tristram Trustie. C. Custance. Sym Suresby.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: And was it none other than ye to me report?

sp.speaker: Tristram.
sp.l: No, and here were ye wished to have seen the sport.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: Would I had, rather than half of that in my purse.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: And I do much rejoice the matter was no worse,
And like as to open it, I was to you faithful,
So of dame Custance honest truth I am joyful.
For God forfend that I should hurt her by false report.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: Well, I will no longer hold her in discomfort.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Now come they hitherward, I trust all shall be well.

sp.speaker: G. Good.
sp.l: Sweet Custance neither heart can think nor tongue tell,
How much I joy in your constant fidelity,
Come now kiss me the pearl of perfect honesty.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: God let me no longer to continue in life,
Than I shall towards you continue a true wife.

sp.speaker: G. Goodl.
sp.l: Well now to make you for this some part of amends,
I shall desire first you, and then such of our friends,
As shall to you seem best, to sup at home with me,
Where at your fought field we shall laugh and merry be.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: And mistress I beseech you, take with me no grief,
I did a true man's part, not wishing your reproof.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Though hasty reports through surmises growing,
May of poor innocentes be utter overthrowing,
Yet because to thy master thou hast a true heart,
And I know mine own truth, I forgive thee for my part.

sp.speaker: G. Goodl.
sp.l: Go we all to my house, and of this gear no more.
Go prepare all things Sym Suresby, hence, run afore.

sp.speaker: Sim Sure.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: G. Good.
sp.l: But who cometh yond, m. Merrygreek?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Roister Doister's champion, I shrew his best cheek.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: Roister Doister self your wooer is with him too.
Surely some thing there is with us they have to do.

div.head: Actus. v. scaena. v.
div.stage: M. Merrygreek. Ralph Roister. Gawyn Goodluck. Tristram Trustie. C. Custance.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Yond I see Gavin Goodluck, to whom lieth my message,
I will first salute him after his long voyage,
And then make all thing well concerning your behalf.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Yea for the pas‚óèe of God.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Hence out of sight ye calf,
Till I have spoke with them, and then I will you ‚óèet,

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: In god's name.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: What master Gavin Goodluck well met
And from your long voyage I bid you right welcome home.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: I come to you from an honest mome.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: Who is that?

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Roister Doister that doughty kite.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Fie, I can scarce abide ye should his name recite.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Ye must take him to favour, and pardon all past,
He heareth of your return, and is full ill aghast.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: I am right well content he have with us some cheer.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Fie upon him beast, then will not I be there.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: Why Custance do ye hate him more than ye love me?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: But for your mind sir, where he were would I not be?

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: He would make us all laugh.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Ye ne'er had better sport.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: I pray you sweet Custance ‚ñ™ let him to us resort.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: To your will I assent.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Why, such a fool it is,
As no man for good pastime would forgo or miss.

sp.speaker: G. Goodl.
sp.l: Fetched him to go with us.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: He will be a glad man.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: We must to make us mirth, maintain him all we can.
And lo yond he cometh and Merrygreek with him.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: At his first entrance ye shall see I will him trim.
But first let us hearken the gentleman's wise talk.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: I pray you mark if ever ye saw crane so stalk.

div.head: Actus. v. scaena. vi.
div.stage: R Roister. M. Merrygreek. C. Custance. G. Goodluck, T. Trustie. D. Doughtie. Harpax.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: May I then be bold?

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: I warrant you on my word,
They say they shall be sick, but ye be at their board.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: They were not angry then.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Yes at first, and made strange
But when I said your anger to favour should change,
And therewith had commended you accordingly,
They were all in love with your maship by and by.
And cried you mercy that they had done you wrong.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: For why, no man, woman, nor child can hate me long.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: We fear (Quod they) he will be avenged one day,
Then for a penny give all our lives we may.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Said they so in deed.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: Did they? yea, even with one voice
He will forgive all (Quod I) o how they did rejoice.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Go fette him (Say they) while he is in good mood,
For have his anger who lust, we will not by the rood.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I pray God that it be all true, that thou hast me told,
And that she fight no more.

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.l: I warrant you, be bold.
Too them, and salute them.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Sirs, I greet you all well.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Your mastership is welcome.

sp.speaker: C. Cust.
sp.l: Saving my quarrel.
For sure I will put you up into the exchequer.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Why so? better nay: wherefore?

sp.speaker: C. Cust.
sp.l: For an usurer.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I am no usurer good mistress by his arms.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: When took he gain of money to any man's harms?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: Yes, a foul usurer he is, ye shall see else.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Didst not thou promise she would pick no more quarrels?

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: He will lend no ‚óèlowes, but he have in recompense
Fifteen for one, which is to much of conscience.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Ah dame, by the ancient law of arms, a man
Hath no honour to foil his hands on a woman.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: And where other usurers take their gains yearly,
This man is angry but he have his by and by.

sp.speaker: Ga. Goodl.
sp.l: Sir, do not for her sake bear me your displeasure.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Well, he shall with you talk thereof more at leisure.
Upon your good usage, he will now shake your hand.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: And much heartily welcome from a strange land.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Be not afeard Gavin to let him shake your fist.

sp.speaker: Ga. Goodl.
sp.l: O the most honest gentleman that ere I wist.
I be your maship to take pain to sup with us.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: He shall not say you nay and I too, by Jesus.
Because ye shall be friends, and let all quarrels pass.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: I will be as good friends with them as ere I was.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Then let me fet your quire that we may have a song.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: Go.

sp.speaker: G. Goodluck.
sp.l: I have heard no melody all this year long.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: Come on sirs quickly.

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Sing on sirs, for my friend's sake.

sp.speaker: D. Dough.
sp.l: Call ye these your friends?

sp.speaker: R. R.
sp.l: Sing on, and no more words make.

sp.speaker: Ga. Good.
sp.l: The lord preserve our most noble Queen of renown,
And her virtue's reward with the heavenly crown.

sp.speaker: C. Custance.
sp.l: The lord strengthen her most excellent majesty,
Long to reign over us in all prosperity.

sp.speaker: T. Trusty.
sp.l: That her godly proceedings the faith to defend,
He may establish and maintain through to the end.

sp.speaker: M. Mery.
sp.l: God grant her as she doth, the gospel to protect,
Learning and virtue to advance, and vice to correct.

sp.speaker: R. Royster.
sp.l: God grant her loving subjects both the mind and grace,
her most godly proceedings worthily to embrace.

sp.speaker: Harpax.
sp.l: Her highness most worthy counsellors God prosper,
With honour and love of all men to minister.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: God grant the nobility her to serve and love,
With all the whole commonty as doth them behove.

div.head: Certain songs to be song by those which shall use this comedy or interlude.

lg.l: Who so to marry a minion wife,
Hath had good chance and hap,
Must love her and cherish her all his life,
And dandle her in his lap.
If she will fare well, if she will go gay,
A good husband ever still,
Whatever she lust to do, or to say,
Must let her have her own will.
About what affairs soever he go,
He must show her all his mind,
None of his counsel she may be kept free,
Else is he a man unkind.
I must be married a Sunday
I must be married a Sunday,
whosoever shall come that way,
I must be married a Sunday.
Roister Doyster is my name,
Roister Doyster is my name,
A lusty brute I am the same,
I must be married a Sunday.
Christian Custance have I found,
Christian Custance have I found,
A widow worth a thousand pound,
I must be married a Sunday.
Custance is as sweet as honey,
Custance is as sweet as honey,
I her lamb and she my coney,
I must be married a Sunday.
When we shall make our wedding feast,
When we shall make our wedding feast,
There shall been cheer for man and beast,
I must be married a Sunday.
I must be married a Sunday. Etc.
Master Roister Doister will straight go home and die,
Our lord Jesus Christ his soul have mercy upon:
Thus you see today a man, to morrow John.
Yet saving for a woman's extreme cruelty,
He might have lived yet a month or two or thr√©e,
but in spite of Custance which hath him wearied,
His mastership shall be worshipfully buried.
And while some piece of his soul is yet him within,
Some part of his funerals let us here begin.
He will go darkling to his grave.
Neque lux, neque crux, nisi solum clink,
Never gentman so went towards heaven I think.
Yet sirs as ye will the bliss of heaven win,
When he cometh to the grave lay him softly in,
And all men take heed by this one gentleman,
How you set your love upon an unkind woman:
For these women be all such mad peevish elves,
They will not be won except it please themselves.
But in faith Custance if ever ye come in hell,
Master Roister Doister shall serve you as well.
Good night Roger old knave, farewell Roger old knave.
Good night Roger old knave, knave, knap.
Nequando, audivi vocem. Requiem aeternam.

div.head: The peal of bells rung by the parish clerk, and Roister Doister's four men.

list.label: the first bell a triple.
list.item: When died he? When died he?
list.label: the second.
list.item: We have him, we have him.
list.label: the third
the fourth bell.
the great bell.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
